audio_caption: The audio features one male speaker delivering a monologue in an informative and somewhat monotonous tone. He is discussing the properties of water, including its characteristic as a universal solvent and the concept of polarity. He explains how polar and nonpolar substances interact with water.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing the role of precipitation from clouds in dissolving minerals in the earth, leading to "salty oceans". The speaker also mentions "solion formation and hydrogen bonding". There is a sudden, short, interjection of speech, "Hi", after which the clip ends.

The audio begins with a male speaker explaining how ions are formed and stating that in a formula of an ionic compound, the number of positive charges equal the number of negative charges. He continues, noting that most atoms have only one stable ion, such as group one and group two metals or halogens, but transition metals can form more than one stable ion.

The audio begins with a male speaker explaining the concept of an ionic compound like sodium chloride. He speaks in an educational tone, describing the ionic bond and the nature of anions. His speech then ends.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining how to name ionic compounds, stating "we use the name of the metal plus the name of the anion". He continues by explaining how to name polyatomic ions by mentioning, "name the cation, the metal or positive ion, first and then name the anion." He then gives the example "NaSO4 is sodium sulfate" and identifies the cation and the anion. Finally, there is a cough at the end of the audio.

A male speaker with a calm and educational tone explains that salts dissolved in water are "hydrated," surrounded by water molecules. He describes the formation of ions when salts dissolve in water, and how these ions can conduct electricity, which he defines as the movement of electrons.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the varying solubility of different salts in water, mentioning that the strength of their ionic bond is a factor. He discusses the solubility of Group 1 and 2 metals and mentions nitrates, chlorides, sulfates, carbonates and hydroxides. A low frequency hum is audible in the background.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing hydrogen bonding and its effect on solubility in water, using table sugar as an example. He adopts an explanatory and instructional tone, noting that sucrose molecules do not dissociate like ionic compounds. He further explains that covalent molecules remain intact in water but form hydrogen bonds. No other speakers, music, or distinct background sounds are present in the clip.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining something related to the Clean Water Act and its role in regulating toxic ions in drinking water. His tone is informative and slightly formal. Following his speech, there is a brief silence.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing regulations and compounds. He notes that regulations also address "compounds like benzene". Some compounds, he explains, are so toxic that the EPA has set a goal of "zero," citing "lead" as an example. The speaker speaks in a calm tone.

The audio clip begins with a man speaking in a calm, informative tone, discussing water stewardship, sewage as a water polluter, and the development of water treatment systems. He mentions primary, secondary, and tertiary treatment stages.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker inquiring about the decision to stop adding fluoride to the water, asking, "What do you think of that?". The male speaker continues with a monologue, describing the stages of a water purification system, mentioning "primary systems" and "tertiary systems", and concludes by posing another question about where medicine winds up. Throughout this, the speaker maintains a neutral, almost informative tone. Lastly, one distinct "act" sound is heard.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing clean water access, conflict-affected and impoverished regions, and the importance of healthy ecosystems. He speaks in a calm, informative tone. He then describes methods of purifying water, including "ion exchangers, reverse osmosis, and distillation," defining how osmosis works with semi-permeable membranes. This is followed by a brief, high-pitched beep sound.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker who says, "the purification of water by distillation on a small scale." He speaks with a somewhat educational or explanatory tone and continues explaining that this is essentially the same process as seen in "the hydrological cycle."
